topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack(R) Carrier Grade (Beta): Adding Disks to Account or Container Rings

body.p: Proxy nodes store account and container objects. When new disks are added to a proxy node, the new disks expand the storage capacity of the account and container rings. We also recommend to use same sets of disks for account and container.

li.xref: Add Disks to an Account or Container Ring

ul.li: HP Helion OpenStack(R) cloud is successfully deployed.(Starter Object Storage (Swift) nodes are functional by default as they are part of cloud deployment.)
At least one Scale-out Proxy node has been deployed.
All of the rings generated must be preserved, preferably at more than one location. Swift requires these rings to be consistent across all nodes.
Make a backup of the rings before any operation.

section.title: Add Disks to an Account or Container Ring
section.p: Perform the following steps to add Swift disk to a ring:

li.p: Log in to the undercloud from seed.
Change the directory to ring builder.
List the scale-out proxy node.
The following sample displays the Proxy nodes:
List the disks on the proxy node.
The following sample displays the lists of disk available on the Proxy node 192.0.2.22.
Format the given disk.
The following sample displays the output of formatted disk of 192.0.2.22.
Note: You can format all the disks with a single command (-d --all).
List the file in the ring building directory. Identify account.builder and container.builder files.
(Optional)If the builder file does not exit in the undercloud, copy the builder files using the following command.

codeblock.codeph: rsync -qzp --rsync-path="sudo rsync" heat-admin@<starter Swift nodes IP address>:/etc/swift/account.builder /root/ring-building/ rsync -qzp --rsync-path="sudo rsync" heat-admin@<starter Swift nodes IP address>:/etc/swift/container.builder /root/ring-building/

li.p: Add the formatted disk to account and container ring(s).

codeblock.codeph: # ringos add-disk-to-ring -f /root/ring-building/account.builder -i <Proxy nodes IP address> -p <port> -d <disk label> -w <weight> -r <region> -z <zone> # ringos add-disk-to-ring -f /root/ring-building/container.builder -i <Proxy nodes IP address> -p <port> -d <disk label> -w <weight> -r <region> -z <zone>

li.p: Note:

ul.li: Choose the zone and region information appropriately.
The disk label is derived from step 5.
The port for the container ring is 6001 and account ring is 6002.

li.p: Recommendation:

ul.li: Add drives gradually using a weighted approach to avoid degraded performance of Swift cluster. The weight will gradually increase by 25% until it becomes 100%. The initial weight is 25.

li.p: Re-balance both account and container ring(s).
List all the Swift nodes.
Copy account.ring.gz and container.ring.gz files to all the nodes.

codeblock.codeph: # ringos copy-ring -s /root/ring-building/account.ring.gz -n <Swift nodes IP address> # ringos copy-ring -s /root/ring-building/container.ring.gz -n <Swift nodes IP address>

li.p: Copy account.builder and container.builder files to all the nodes.

codeblock.codeph: # ringos copy-ring -s /root/ring-building/account.builder -n <Swift nodes IP address> # ringos copy-ring -s /root/ring-building/container.builder -n <Swift nodes IP address>

li.p: Note: The .buldier and .ring.gz files must be present in the Swift nodes.
Set the weight of the disks using the following command:

codeblock.codeph: # ringos set-weight -f /root/ring-building/account.builder -s <disk id> -w <weight> # ringos set-weight -f /root/ring-building/container.builder -s <disk id> -w <weight>

li.p: Repeat steps from 8-12 increasing the weight by 25 each time; set the weight to 50, 75, and finally 100 (w= 50, 75, 100) .
